question: Under Rule 86.2 of Part 86, describe the procedural steps for a stakeholder seeking a court direction as to whom to pay a debt when competing claims exist, including (i) the court to which the stakeholder application should be made depending on whether a claim is pending, (ii) the form to be filed, (iii) the required contents of the stakeholder's witness statement in support of the application, (iv) the persons on whom the stakeholder must serve the application, and (v) the time limit and required filing/serving of a witness statement by a respondent, and identify any other substantive requirements set out in rules 86.2(1)-(6).
truth: A stakeholder may apply to the court for a direction as to whom to pay a debt or to whom to give any goods or chattels. The correct forum depends on whether a claim is pending against the stakeholder: if there is an existing claim pending against the stakeholder, the application must be made to the court in which that existing claim is pending; if no claim is pending, the application must be made to the court in which the stakeholder might be sued. The stakeholder application must be made using a Part 8 claim form, unless it is being made in an existing claim, in which case it must be made by an application notice in accordance with Part 23. The application must be supported by a witness statement stating that the stakeholder (a) claims no interest in the subject-matter beyond charges or costs, (b) does not collude with any of the claimants to that subject-matter, and (c) is willing to pay or transfer the subject-matter into court or to dispose of it as the court may direct. The stakeholder must serve the claim form or application notice on all other persons who, so far as they are aware, asserts a claim to the subject-matter of the stakeholder application. A respondent who is served must within 14 days file at court and serve on the stakeholder a witness statement specifying any money and describing any goods and chattels. These provisions establish the procedural framework for a stakeholder seeking a direction in the face of competing claims. [Part 86 Stakeholder Claims and Applications]
source_type: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: In the scope and interpretation provisions, how is 'financial restrictions proceedings' defined, and what are the two subtypes under that definition? Also identify the exact Acts referred to by the shorthand 'the 2008 Act', 'the 2010 Act' and 'the 2018 Act', and define 'appropriate Minister' as used in this Part.
truth: The term 'financial restrictions proceedings' is defined in 79.1(2) as comprising two subtypes: (i) financial restrictions proceedings within the meaning of section 65 of the 2008 Act; and (ii) proceedings in the High Court on an application under section 27 of the 2010 Act, or on a claim arising from any matter to which such an application relates. The shorthand references are defined as follows: 'the 2008 Act' means the Counter-Terrorism Act 2008; 'the 2010 Act' means the Terrorist Asset-Freezing etc Act 2010; 'the 2018 Act' means the Sanctions and Anti-Money Laundering Act 2018. The term 'appropriate Minister' means, for a challenge to a decision of the Secretary of State, the Secretary of State; and for a challenge to a decision of the Treasury, the Treasury. [Proceedings under the counter-terrorism act 2008, part 1 of the terrorist asset-freezing etc. act 2010 and part 1 of the sanctions and anti-money laundering act 2018]
source_type: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: Under Part 87, outline the procedural requirements for applying to the High Court for a writ of habeas corpus for release, including (i) how the application is to be made, (ii) who may sign the witness statement and in what circumstances, (iii) where the claim form is to be filed, (iv) whether the application can be brought without notice and the conditions under which this may occur, (v) what a judge may do in urgent cases regarding the claim form, and (vi) how the application may be considered at first instance by a single judge.
truth: The applicant must file a claim form under Part 8 and a witness statement or affidavit to bring a writ of habeas corpus for release. The witness statement or affidavit must state that the application is made at the instance of the person being detained, set out the nature of the detention, and, subject to paragraph 87.2(3), be made by the detained person. If the detained person cannot make the witness statement or affidavit, it may be made by another person on behalf of the detained person, and the statement must explain the reason why the detained person is unable to make it. The claim form must be filed in the Administrative Court. The application may be made without notice. In cases of urgency, the judge may dispense with the requirement that a claim form must be filed and must give directions for the conduct of the application. A judge may consider the application initially on paper. [Part 87 Applications for writ of habeas corpus]
source_type: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: Under Practice Direction 65, explain how an on-notice injunction application under Part V of the 1996 Act, Part 4 of the 2009 Act, or Part 1 of the 2014 Act should be initiated and managed when the originating proceedings began in a youth court and were later transferred to the County Court after the respondent attains 18. In your answer, address: (a) the required form for such applications and how it is treated for Part 8 purposes; (b) where the application on notice is issued and how it is subsequently routed between County Court hearing centres; (c) the effect of any youth court action on continuing the proceedings once transferred to the High Court or County Court; (d) which County Court hearing centre handles the transfer and the criterion used to determine that centre; and (e) the practical risk of delay if the application is not filed at the appropriate hearing centre in the first instance.
truth:
(a) The application must be made using form N 16 A for injunctions under Chapter III of Part V of the 1996 Act, Part 4 of the 2009 Act, or Part 1 of the 2014 Act. For the purposes of applying Part 8 to applications under Section I or Section VIII of Part 65, form N 16 A shall be treated as the Part 8 claim form (i.e., N 16 A is the vehicle and is treated as a Part 8 claim form). [Practice Direction 65, section 1.1(1)].

(b) An application on notice under rules 65.3 or 65.43 will be issued by the County Court hearing centre where the claim is made. However, after issue, the application will be sent to the County Court hearing centre which serves the address where the defendant resides or where the conduct complained of occurred. The applicant should consider potential delay if the application is not made at the appropriate hearing centre in the first instance. [Practice Direction 65, section 1.1(2)].

(c) Where proceedings under Part 4 of the 2009 Act or Part 1 of the 2014 Act commenced in a youth court have been transferred to the High Court or County Court after the respondent attained the age of 18, anything done in the youth court in relation to those proceedings will have effect for the purposes of continuing the proceedings in the High Court or County Court, as if it had been done in the High Court or County Court as the case may be. This ensures continuity of proceedings despite the transfer. [Practice Direction 65, sections 1 A.1].

(d) Proceedings transferred to the County Court will be sent to the County Court hearing centre which serves the address where the respondent resides. This governs where the case is ultimately managed within the County Court system post-transfer. [Practice Direction 65, section 1 A.2].

(e) The practical risk of delay arises from routing requirements: if an application is not made at the appropriate County Court hearing centre in the first instance, the subsequent routing of the application to the correct centre (to serve the address where the defendant resides or the conduct occurred) may cause delays. Applicants should therefore consider these potential delays when deciding where to initiate the application. [Practice Direction 65, section 1.1(2)]. 

Source: Practice Direction 65.
source_type: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: Consider a personal injury claim in which expert evidence is to be used under CPR Part 35. Explain, with reference to Practice Direction 35, the duties and limitations imposed on an expert (sections 2.1–2.5) including independence, objectivity, consideration of all material facts, and disclosure of lack of expertise or inability to reach a definite opinion. Explain the process for updating opinions after the report is produced. Then, explain the special 2.6 requirement for first medical reports in fixed-cost cases: (a) soft tissue injury claims and (b) whiplash injuries, including the requirement that the first report be obtained from an accredited medical expert selected via the Med Co Portal. Finally, assess whether the PD 35 text itself prescribes any sanctions for breach.
truth: Answer: Practice Direction 35 imposes a structured, integrity-focused framework on expert evidence under CPR Part 35. The key duties are as follows. (a) Independence (2.1): The expert must provide an independent product, uninfluenced by litigation pressures, and not be swayed by the interests of any party. (b) Objectivity and non-advocacy (2.2): The expert should assist the court by giving objective, unbiased opinions on matters within their expertise and must not assume the role of an advocate for any party. (c) Consideration of all material facts (2.3): The expert must consider all material facts, including those that might detract from their opinions. (d) Disclosure of limits of expertise (2.4): The expert must clearly state when a question or issue falls outside their expertise (2.4(a)) and when they are not able to reach a definite opinion due to insufficient information (2.4(b)). (e) Change of view (2.5): If, after producing a report, the expert’s view changes on any material matter, the change must be communicated to all parties without delay, and where appropriate to the court. (f) Fixed-cost medical reports – general and portal-based accreditation (2.6): In soft tissue injury claims where permission is given for a fixed-cost medical report, the first report must be obtained from an accredited medical expert selected via the Med Co Portal (website: www.medco.org.uk). (g) Specifics for whiplash (2.6(1A)): In a claim for a whiplash injury, whether or not part of a claim for other injuries, where permission is given for a fixed-cost medical report, the first report must be obtained from an accredited medical expert selected via the Med Co Portal. These provisions are complemented by the Guidance for the Instruction of Experts in Civil Claims 2014 and annexes referenced in Practice Direction 35. (Sanctions): The text of Practice Direction 35 as provided does not specify explicit sanctions for breach; it sets duties and procedures intended to guide conduct and ensure reliability of expert evidence. For enforcement or disciplinary consequences, CPR Part 35 and related rules would apply beyond the PD. [Practice Direction 35]

category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: Under Practice Direction 73, rule 73.3, what are the mandatory contents of the application notice for a charging order, and how does the form chosen (N379 for land, N380 for securities) relate to those requirements? Additionally, explain how asset identification should be carried out for land versus securities, how rule 1.3 governs the handling of multiple assets in a single application, and where the application notice must be filed.
truth: The application notice must be filed using Practice Form N 379 if the charge relates to land, or N 380 if it relates to securities. The application notice must contain: (1) the name and address of the judgment debtor; (2) details of the judgment or order sought to be enforced; (3) the amount of money remaining due under the judgment or order; (4) if the judgment debt is payable by instalments, (a) whether the order was made on or after 1 October 2012, and (b) the amount of any instalments which have fallen due and remain unpaid; (5) if the judgment creditor knows of the existence of any other creditors of the judgment debtor, their names and (if known) their addresses; (6) identification of the asset or assets which it is intended to charge, including, where applicable, the title number under which any land upon which it is sought to impose a charge is registered; (7) details of the judgment debtor's interest in the asset; and (8) the names and addresses of the persons on whom an interim charging order must be served under rule 73.7. The asset identification requires land to include the title number (where applicable), whereas for securities there is no such land-title requirement; in all cases the asset must be identified. Under rule 1.3, a judgment creditor may apply in a single application notice for charging orders over more than one asset, but if the court makes interim charging orders over more than one asset, it will draw up a separate order relating to each asset. Rule 1.4 sets out the filing address for County Court applications to the Civil National Business Centre: Civil National Business Centre, St Katharine's House, 21-27 St Katharine's Street, Northampton, NN 1 2 LH, DX 702885 Northampton 7. [Practice Direction 73]
source_type: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: Describe the lifecycle of trial-length estimates under D.16, including (i) how the initial estimate is produced at the Case Management Conference and its relation to the trial timetable; (ii) how the Court treats particularly long estimates and the consideration of whether all issues should be heard in a single hearing; (iii) the requirement for a confirmed estimate to be attached to the pre-trial checklist and the signatories; (iv) the ongoing duty to review estimates and the process for revising them; and (v) the Court's approach to accuracy and acceptance of estimates.
truth: At the Case Management Conference, an estimate of the minimum and maximum lengths of the trial (inclusive of reading time) must be made, having regard to the requirements of a trial timetable (J5.4(b)); this estimate will appear in the pre-trial timetable and will be the basis on which a trial date is fixed. For longer estimates, the Court examines with particular care and will wish to consider, with the assistance of advocates, whether for especially long trials all issues should be heard at the same hearing (see J1.4). A confirmed estimate of the minimum and maximum lengths, signed by the advocates who are to appear at the trial, should be attached to the pre-trial checklist. The provisional estimate and, after it is given, the confirmed estimate must be kept under review by the advocates who are to appear at the trial; if at any stage an estimate needs to be revised, a signed revised estimate (whether agreed or not) should be submitted by the advocates to the Commercial Court Listing Office. Accurate estimation of trial length is of great importance to the efficient functioning of the Court; the Court will be guided by, but will not necessarily accept, the estimates given by the parties. [D.  Case Management in the Commercial Court, D.16 Estimates of length of trial (p. 54)]

question: Under D.17 Pre-Trial Review and trial timetable, outline the precise sequence and requirements for a pre-trial review in a Commercial Court case, including (i) the normal and potential earlier timing of the PTR, (ii) who should normally conduct and attend the PTR, (iii) the procedure for the parties to agree a trial timetable including the filing obligations and timing, and (iv) the powers of the Judge at the PTR or at the start of trial to determine the timetable and give directions, including any relevant cross-references to PD58 and J5.4(b).
truth: A pre-trial review is ordered when the court considers it will assist in ensuring readiness for trial and in planning the trial hearing (D.17.1). The pre-trial review normally occurs between 8 and 2 weeks before the date fixed for trial, but may be earlier in particularly long or complex cases (D.17.2). When possible, the pre-trial review will be conducted by the trial Judge, and it should be attended by the advocates who are to appear at the trial (D.17.3; PD58 §11.2). Before the pre-trial review, or if there is no pre-trial review before the start of the trial (see J.3), the parties must attempt to agree a timetable for the trial; the claimant must file a copy of the draft timetable at least two days before the date fixed for the pre-trial review, or at least seven days before the start of the trial if there is no pre-trial review; any differences of view should be clearly identified and briefly explained (D.17.4; PD58 §11.4; J5.4(b)). At the pre-trial review, or before or at the beginning of the trial itself if there is no pre-trial review, the Judge may set a timetable for the trial and give such other directions for the conduct of the trial as they consider appropriate (D.17.4). F7.2 applies also to pre-trial reviews (D.17.5). [D.  Case Management in the Commercial Court, D.17 Pre-Trial Review and trial timetable (p. 55)]

question: According to Appendix 15: Guidance on disclosure where PD 57AD does not apply (p. 196), what forms of disclosure orders may the Court make under rule 31.5(7), when is the Court typically asked to consider these orders, and what conditions apply if the form or scope of disclosure is not agreed? Additionally, outline the party obligations regarding preservation of documents, disclosure statements, and any disclosure search limits that must be disclosed.
truth: The Court will normally consider what orders to make in relation to disclosure under rule 31.5(7) at the first Case Management Conference. The Court may: (a) use a combination of orders; (b) order a mixture of forms of disclosure; (c) order sample disclosure; (d) order disclosure in stages; or (e) order that disclosure is dispensed with, either generally or in relation to certain issues, or is to be given only in relation to certain issues. If the form or scope of disclosure is not agreed, the party seeking the more extensive form or scope should justify the order by reference to the overriding objective. In addition to the form of disclosure, the duty to preserve documents arises whenever litigation is contemplated: parties must take all reasonable steps to preserve disclosable documents, notify their clients of the need to preserve, and the duty extends to electronic documents that would otherwise be deleted under ordinary retention policies. The parties and their legal representatives must cooperate to ensure that disclosure appropriate to the needs of the case is given and that the process is efficient and effective, particularly for electronic documents; discussions concerning disclosure may begin before proceedings in heavy and complex matters and should begin well in advance of the first Case Management Conference. Each party should make a disclosure statement, verified by a statement of truth, confirming it has carried out the disclosure ordered, and where a reasonable search is required the disclosure statement should state any limits placed upon the search on the grounds that otherwise the search would be unreasonable. [Appendix 15: Guidance on disclosure where PD 57AD does not apply (p. 196)]

question: Explain the duties and conduct obligations of a Technology and Construction Court expert under CPR Part 35 in relation to Section 13.7 Experts' Reports and Section 13.8 Presentation of Expert Evidence, focusing on: (i) the duty to assist the court overriding duties to the client; (ii) the requirement that each expert's report be independent and unbiased; (iii) how issues are identified and how the expert determines the detailed contents and format of the report, including permissible guidance from the instructing party about length, extracts, sourcing, and supplementary material; (iv) the role of the Protocol for the Instruction of Experts to give Evidence in Civil Claims, particularly paragraph 15.2 provisions allowing amendments to ensure accuracy, internal consistency, completeness, relevance, or clarity; and (v) the purpose and acceptable modes of presenting expert evidence at the commencement of their evidence, including a summary of main issues either orally or by PowerPoint. In your answer, reference the specific guidance contained in the cited sections.
truth: A TCC expert must put the court’s welfare first by complying with the duty to help the court on matters within his expertise, even where that conflicts with duties to the instructing party; this overriding duty is stated in CPR 35.3 and reflected in 13.7.1. Each report must be independent and unbiased (13.7.1). The parties must identify the issues with which the expert should deal, but the expert retains control over the detailed contents and format of the report, provided the report complies with the Practice Direction supplementing CPR Part 35 and the Protocol for the Instruction of Experts to give Evidence in Civil Claims; where requested by the instructing party, the report should (a) be as short as reasonably possible, (b) avoid copious extracts, (c) identify the source of any opinion or data relied upon, and (d) avoid annexing more than reasonably necessary to support the opinions (13.7.2). The Protocol allows legal advisors to invite amendments to ensure accuracy, internal consistency, completeness, relevance, and clarity (15.2). The purpose of expert evidence is to assist the court with technical or scientific matters, and in large/complex cases it is often helpful for the expert to provide at the outset a summary of their views on the main issues, either orally or by a presentation (e.g., PowerPoint) (13.8.1). [Section 13. Expert evidence, 13.7 Experts' Reports (p. 87)]

question: Under Section 7.2 of the ADR guidance in the Technology and Construction Court, explain how the court approaches the timing of ADR from pre-action to post-first CMC stages, including (a) the cost implications of ADR at different stages, (b) the interaction with the TCC Pre-Action Protocol's face-to-face meeting and its impact on a potential stay, (c) what the first CMC requires the court to consider about ADR and stays, (d) how the court may revisit ADR decisions after the first CMC and before trial, (e) who decides the appropriate ADR procedure and the role of mediation as the default, and (f) the court’s power to issue an ADR order referred to in 7.3.2.
truth: ADR may be appropriate before the proceedings have begun or at any subsequent stage; however, later ADR tends to incur higher and often unnecessary costs, so timing requires careful consideration. The TCC Pre-Action Protocol requires at least one face-to-face meeting between the parties before proceedings, with sufficient time to discuss and resolve the dispute; because this procedure has taken place, the court will not necessarily grant a stay of proceedings upon demand and must be satisfied that any adjournment is actually necessary to enable ADR to take place. At the first CMC, the court will want views on the likely efficacy of ADR, the appropriate timing of ADR, and the advantages and disadvantages of a short stay to allow ADR; after considering the representations, the court may order a short stay to facilitate ADR at that stage, or alternatively encourage the parties to seek ADR and allow it to occur within the court's timetable for resolution. At any stage after the first CMC and before trial, the court may consider afresh the likely efficacy of ADR and whether a short stay should be granted to facilitate ADR, either on its own initiative or if requested by one or both parties. In an appropriate case, the court may indicate the type of ADR it considers suitable, with mediation as the typical ADR procedure in most cases, though the decision in this regard remains with the parties. If at any stage the court considers it appropriate, an ADR order may be issued in the terms of the applicable Appendix (the extract provided cuts off here), illustrating the court’s power to impose an ADR order where warranted. [Section 7. ADR, 7.2 Timing (p. 54)]

question: According to Section 7.1 of the ADR guide for the Technology and Construction Court, what does ADR mean in this context, what forms may ADR take, what is the court's role regarding ADR, and what is expected of legal representatives before the first CMC?
truth: ADR is defined in this Guide as any voluntary process through which the parties attempt to resolve their dispute. In practice, ADR most commonly takes the form of inter-party negotiations or a mediation conducted by a neutral mediator, with alternative forms including early neutral evaluation by a judge or another neutral person who receives concise presentations from each party and then provides his or her own evaluation of the case. The court will provide encouragement to the parties to use ADR and will, whenever appropriate, facilitate its use. Although the TCC is an appropriate forum for IT and construction/engineering disputes, the use of ADR can lead to significant cost savings and may result in a settlement satisfactory to all parties. Legal representatives should ensure their clients are fully aware of the benefits of ADR and that the use of ADR has been carefully considered prior to the first CMC. [Section 7. ADR, 7.1 General (p. 54)]

question: Identify and explain the four obligations imposed on the Recipient at the conclusion of the Dispute under clause 5.1, and explain how clause 5.2 interacts with retention requirements under law or regulatory rules, including who may retain a copy and the continued application of the agreement to retained materials.
truth: Under clause 5.1, at the conclusion of the Dispute the Recipient must: (A) destroy all documents and materials containing, reflecting, incorporating or based on the Confidential Information; (B) to the extent technically practicable, erase all the Confidential Information from its computer and communications systems and devices used by it, or stored in electronic form; (C) ensure that its Representatives who receive the Confidential Information comply with these obligations; and (D) certify in writing to the Discloser that it has complied with the requirements of clause 5.1. Clause 5.2 provides that the obligations in clause 5.1 do not require destruction or return of documents and materials that the Recipient is required to retain by applicable law, or to satisfy the requirements of a regulatory authority or body of competent jurisdiction or the rules of any listing authority or stock exchange. The Recipient’s legal representatives can retain one complete set of all documents which would otherwise be destroyed. The provisions of this agreement shall continue to apply to any documents and materials retained by the Recipient (including those retained by its legal representatives). [5. Intellectual Property Court Users' Committee (p. 2)]

question: Under 12. Arrangements for listing (p. 7) of the Patents Court Practice, what is the step-by-step process for listing a short application (estimated to last no more than 1 hour) when the parties cannot reach agreement on a hearing date, including: (i) who is responsible for listing and where is the listing office located; (ii) how to initiate contact and what lead times apply; (iii) how to obtain an appointment and the required notice to interested parties; (iv) the prohibition on \

Under 13.1–13.3 of the Patents Court guidance, what are the precise obligations on parties when preparing time estimates and technical complexity ratings for a hearing or trial, and what steps must be taken if those estimates become unrealistic?
truth: Time estimates must be realistic and accurate and must include a discrete reading time for the court to read the papers prior to the hearing or trial. In formulating the reading time, counsel should reflect that the court will wish to read the skeleton arguments, the patent (where relevant), the prior art (where relevant), expert reports, and other key documents (e.g., substantive witness statements); advisors should bear in mind the technical difficulty of the case when determining the reading time. The court may impose guillotines where time estimates are in danger of being exceeded. For technical complexity, the rating must be realistic and accurate and should take account of the complexity of both the patent and the prior art, as well as the complexity of the infringement issues and the likely evidence. If a time estimate provided (e.g., at a CMC) becomes unrealistic, parties have a duty to notify the Chancery Listing Office or, where appropriate, the judge's clerk as soon as possible with a revised time estimate; the same duty applies to revised estimates of technical complexity. [13. Time estimates and technical complexity ratings (p. 8)]

question: An order is made under CPR 3.3(4) without a hearing, and the order states that any party affected may apply to have it set aside, varied or stayed, with the right to do so to be exercised within 7 days after service (or within a specified period if one is stated). A party seeks to challenge this order by (i) applying under Part 23 to set aside the order within the 7-day window, (ii) filing a subsequent application under CPR 3.3(5) arguing the later relief to vary or set aside is based on new material, and (iii) appealing the original order. In addition, the defence has been filed and the court has issued a notice of proposed allocation under Annex 6, with directions to file a Direction Questionnaire (DQ) by the required date. Explain, with precise reference to the text, the proper routes for challenging the 3.3(4) order, the time limits that apply, the consequences if the 7-day period expires, how a second 3.3(5) application should be treated (including the role of Collier v Williams [2006] EWCA Civ 20) and when such an application might be considered an abuse of process, the difference between an application under 3.3(5) and an appeal, and how these challenges interact with the Notice of Allocation and directions process described in 10.3–10.4. Your answer should be framed using UK legal terminology and reference the source document. End with the required citation.
truth:
Key framework and routes for challenging a 3.3(4) order:()
- Nature of the order: A CPR 3.3(4) order is an order made by the court under its case-management power without a hearing. The order must contain a statement of the right to apply to have it set aside, varied or stayed. The right must be exercised within such period as may be specified; if no period is specified, the period is 7 days after service of the order on the affected party. Such an application should be made by the Part 23 procedure. The court may, under CPR 23.8, determine that a hearing would not be appropriate. Any challenge to such an order is by way of appeal. [10. Case Management (p. 92)]

A. Primary challenge route: Part 23 application to set aside/var y/stay (CPR 3.3(4))
- The affected party may apply to set aside, vary or stay the order via a Part 23 process within the 7-day window (or any specified period in the order). The application is typically made under Part 23, and the hearing may occur in person, unless CPR 23.8 allows a non-hearing determination. This is the procedural mechanism for reviewing the 3.3(4) order itself, rather than merely appealing it on its merits. [10. Case Management (p. 92)]
- Time limit and form: The time limit is the period specified in the order; if none is specified, 7 days after service. The form of challenge is a Part 23 application. [10. Case Management (p. 92)]

B. Second challenge route: CPR 3.3(5) application to set aside or vary; abuse of process concerns (Collier v Williams)
- If a party applies to set aside or vary the order under CPR 3.3(5) (whether on paper or at a hearing), any further application under 3.3(5) should ordinarily be struck out as an abuse of process unless it is based on substantially different material from the earlier application. This principle is stated with reference to Collier v Williams [2006] EWCA Civ 20. [10. Case Management (p. 92)]
- Practical implication: A later 3.3(5) application will generally be disallowed as an abuse of process unless the party shows substantially new material that could not have been raised in the earlier application, thereby allowing the court to entertain a fresh consideration on that basis. The Collier v Williams guidance governs when successive 3.3(5) applications are permissible. [10. Case Management (p. 92)]

C. Distinction and interplay with appeal
- Although a 3.3(4) order may be challenged via a Part 23 application under 3.3(4) or 3.3(5), the text expressly notes that “any challenge to such an order is by way of appeal.” This indicates that, ultimately, if the substantive objections to the order persist, an appeal lies as a separate remedy beyond any interim Part 23 challenge. The Part 23 route is for immediate relief or variation, whereas the appeal route provides a full appellate review of the order’s merits. [10. Case Management (p. 92)]

D. Interaction with Notice of Allocation and directions (10.3–10.4)
- After a defence is filed, the court serves a notice of proposed allocation (the standard RCJ Annex 6 notice). This notice allocates the claim to the Multi-track and provides an opportunity for the parties to explain any objections. The parties are required to seek to agree proposed directions before the date for filing Direction Questionnaires (DQ). The notice requires the parties to file by the date specified. The purpose of the directions is to promote agreement and to enable the Master to identify the issues in dispute; assuming the parties comply with filing a DQ, the court will allocate the claim to the multi-track in appropriate cases. (10.3–10.4)
- Interaction with the 3.3(4) order: The presence of a 3.3(4) order does not suspend or replace the allocation/directions process; rather, the challenge route to the order (Part 23 or appeal) operates alongside the normal case-management sequencing. If a party seeks to set aside or vary the 3.3(4) order via Part 23 or by appeal, those proceedings will run concurrently with, or be coordinated with, the ongoing allocation and DQ timetable. The court will continue with allocation and directions as per 10.3–10.4 unless the 3.3(4) order directly affects those steps and a separate order to stay or modify directions is sought and granted. [10. Case Management (p. 92)]

E. Practical sequencing and risk areas
- Timeliness: The 7-day window is strict unless a different period is specified in the order; failure to act within that window may foreclose the right to relief under the Part 23 process unless the court extends time or considers exceptional circumstances. [10. Case Management (p. 92)]
- Abuse of process: Repeated 3.3(5) applications will be subject to abuse-of-process scrutiny unless substantially different material is introduced, as per Collier v Williams. This guards against forum shopping and unnecessary repetition of applications. [10. Case Management (p. 92)]
- Choice of route: If the objective is immediate relief or alteration of the 3.3(4) order’s effect, a Part 23 application is appropriate; for a comprehensive treatment of the order’s merits, an appeal is the proper route. The text emphasizes that challenges are by appeal, reinforcing that Part 23 is for interim relief while an appeal provides final resolution. [10. Case Management (p. 92)]
- Coordination with case management: Regardless of the challenge route, the allocation process (Annex 6) and the DQ timetable operate to identify issues and allocate to the multi-track where appropriate; the court will usually proceed with case-management directions unless a stay or variation of those steps is granted in the challenge. [10. Case Management (p. 92)]

Conclusion: In the scenario described, the appropriate first step to challenge the 3.3(4) order is to pursue a Part 23 application to set aside, vary, or stay within the period (7 days unless a different period is specified), noting that the court may determine the matter without a hearing under CPR 23.8. If additional or repeated relief is sought, a subsequent 3.3(5) application would generally be regarded as an abuse of process unless accompanied by substantially different material from the prior application (as per Collier v Williams). If the party wishes to challenge the order on its merits, an appeal remains available. All of this occurs alongside the normal allocation process (Annex 6) and the requirement to file a Direction Questionnaire by the prescribed date, with directions aimed at clarifying issues in dispute and facilitating multi-track allocation where appropriate. [10. Case Management (p. 92)]

question: In a high-value personal injury claim in the King's Bench Division, parties are preparing a costs budget for the claim's lifecycle. The sums in issue are £5,000,000. Non-monetary relief in issue is valued at £0. The case is assessed as highly complex with novel questions on causation and liability. The defendant's conduct has generated additional work, estimated at a 30% uplift in time and cost relative to a typical case of this type due to extended disclosure obligations and procedural steps. The claimant is a vulnerable party (capacity limited) and a witness is also vulnerable. There is potential public interest and reputational factors surrounding the case. The parties propose a total costs budget of £1,000,000 (Stage 1: £320,000; Stage 2: £680,000). Apply CPR 44.3(5) (proportionality) and CPR 44.4(2) (reasonableness) as described in Annex 8, to determine whether the proposed budget is proportionate and reasonable, identify which factors support or undermine proportionateness, and advise on whether and how the budget should be adjusted, including any recommended revised figures and the rationale for them.
truth:
Answer:

1. Governing framework (Annex 8). The note reiterates two linked tests that govern budgeting in high-value personal injury/clinical negligence claims: (i) proportionality under CPR 44.3(5), which requires costs incurred to bear a reasonable relationship to (a) sums in issue, (b) value of non-monetary relief, (c) complexity, (d) any additional work generated by the paying party’s conduct, (e) wider factors such as reputation or public importance, and (f) any additional work due to vulnerability of a party or any witness; and (ii) reasonableness under CPR 44.4(2), which concerns the amount or value involved, the particular complexity or difficulty/novelty, the skill/effort/knowledge/responsibility involved, and the place and circumstances in which work is to be done. The court must have regard to both tests when assessing a costs budget. [Annex 8. Senior Master’s note on Cost Budgeting]

2. Application to the scenario – proportionate test under CPR 44.3(5).

- Sums in issue (a): The claim value in issue is £5,000,000. The proposed total budget is £1,000,000. The relationship is 1,000,000 / 5,000,000 = 20%. A proportionality assessment asks whether the budget bears a reasonable relationship to the sums in issue. In a high-value, complex case, a 20% ratio may be defensible where other proportionality factors (notably complexity, additional work, and vulnerability) justify a higher budget; conversely, given the significant sums in issue, the court may expect a robust budget reflecting the scale of potential relief and the need for thorough preparation. The note requires consideration of the proportionality relationship to the sums in issue, among other factors. 

- Non-monetary relief in issue (b): £0. While this reduces the monetary yardstick for proportionality, the test also captures other factors (complexity, additional work, vulnerability). The absence of non-monetary relief does not by itself render the budget non-proportional if other factors justify costs.

- Complexity (c): The case is described as highly complex with novel causation issues. The note’s proportionality test explicitly requires regard to complexity, which weighs strongly in favour of a more substantial budget. High complexity tends to increase the reasonable relationship between costs and sums in issue, potentially justifying a larger budget than the baseline 20% here.

- Additional work generated by the paying party’s conduct (d): A 30% uplift due to extended disclosure and procedural steps has been identified. This factor supports a higher budget and aligns with the requirement that costs be proportionate to work generated by the paying party’s conduct.

- Wider factors (e): Public importance or reputational concerns can justify a higher costs budget if relevant to the proceedings. If there is genuine public interest or reputational risk, this supports a larger budget.

- Vulnerability (f): The claimant’s vulnerability (capacity limitations) and vulnerability of a witness entail additional protective measures, care in case management, and potentially more time and resources. This factor supports a higher budget.

Overall assessment under CPR 44.3(5): The proposed budget sits at £1,000,000 for sums in issue of £5,000,000 with 30% uplift for defendant conduct and vulnerability factors. Given the high complexity and vulnerability, there is a reasonable argument that the budget should be proportionate on the basis that the costs are commensurate with the additional work and safeguarding requirements, and with any public-interest considerations. However, the proportionate relationship to the £5m sums is not automatically satisfied by a 20% budget where multiple qualitative factors are strongly in play. The court would scrutinise whether the uplift from complexity, vulnerability, and conduct justifies a higher proportion of the sums in issue than 20%.

3. Application to the scenario – reasonableness test under CPR 44.4(2).

- Amount/value of money involved (a): Sums in issue are £5m; the proposed budget is £1m. The budget should reflect the value of the money involved and the work required to protect it. The 1:5 ratio is not determinative, but the budget should be robust enough to cover detailed investigations, disclosure, and expert work.

- Complexity (b): As noted, the case is highly complex with novel questions; this supports a larger budget, given the need for multiple experts, extensive document review, and sophisticated causation analysis.

- Skill/effort/specialised knowledge (c): Personal injury/clinical negligence matters typically require high levels of specialism (quantum experts, liability experts, medical professionals). The budget must reflect the level of skill and responsibility required.

- Place and circumstances (d): Not specified in the scenario; if it involves specialist courts, out-of-area experts, or complex logistics, these would further justify a larger budget. In the absence of such specifics, this factor neither pushes upwards nor downwards significantly.

Overall assessment under CPR 44.4(2): The budget must reflect the substantial complexity and the increased effort due to the defendant’s conduct, as well as the vulnerability considerations. A £1,000,000 budget is plausible but may be understated given the high complexity, potential need for multiple rounds of disclosure, numerous experts, and safeguarding obligations. The reasonableness test would require demonstrating that the budget is appropriate to achieve or secure a just resolution, without overproviding. On balance, the proposed figure is arguable but warrants justification of uplift for the 30% extra work and for vulnerability, with sensitivity to the substantial sums in issue.

4. Recommendations on adjustment and revised figures (practical approach for the court).

- If the court accepts the need to reflect the 30% uplift due to defendant conduct and the vulnerability/complexity factors, a recalibration of the budget is prudent. The proportionality and reasonableness guidance would commonly support a budget that more accurately mirrors the volume of work and safeguarding costs anticipated.

- Proposed revised budget (illustrative): Increase the total costs budget to reflect the 30% uplift plus an additional uplift for vulnerability and complexity. A reasonable adjustment might target around £1.3m–£1.5m total (for example, Stage 1 £420,000 and Stage 2 £900,000, totaling £1,320,000, or Stage 1 £450,000 and Stage 2 £1,020,000 totaling £1,470,000). This aligns with the need to cover extensive disclosure, expert reports, and welfare considerations for a vulnerable claimant and vulnerable witness, while still anchoring the budget to the sums in issue.

- Alternatively, if the court remains cautious about uplift discretion, the parties could propose a staged budget with a clearly stated uplift rationale (30% for additional work due to defendant conduct, plus a vulnerability allowance of, for example, 5–15% depending on the level of safeguarding and expert requirements) rather than a fixed percentage. The court would then determine whether the stage-by-stage budgets are proportionate and reasonable in light of the factors in CPR 44.3(5) and 44.4(2).

- Non-monetary relief remains £0; ensure that any potential future non-monetary relief is scoped to avoid unnecessary budgeting for elements outside issue.

- In all events, the court should require the parties to provide a precise breakdown of time/costs by stage, together with a narrative explanation linking each line item to the factors set out in CPR 44.3(5) and 44.4(2), in order to facilitate transparent proportionality assessment.

5. Conclusion.

The proposed £1,000,000 budget engages multiple proportionality and reasonableness factors: it is influenced by high complexity, the 30% uplift for defendant conduct, and the vulnerabilities involved. While the budget may be proportionate given the qualitative factors, the court would be justified in requesting a justification of the uplift and potentially adjusting the total upwards to reflect the significant work anticipated from complexity, vulnerability, and safeguarding requirements. The final determination should be grounded in a stage-by-stage breakdown that ties each item to the factors in CPR 44.3(5) and 44.4(2), with clear justification for any uplift beyond the baseline proportionate relation to sums in issue.

[Annex 8. Senior Master's note on Cost Budgeting]

question: According to the Introduction (p. 15) of the King's Bench Division Guide, what are the conditions under which standard forms of order may be modified for use in proceedings started in the Central Office, particularly regarding (a) the information content of the modification, (b) the treatment of the Royal Arms, and (c) the Guide's legal status and its relation to the CPR/PDs and the overriding objective?
truth: Answer: (a) Modification of standard forms is permissible where individual cases require it, but the modified form must contain at least as full information or guidance as would have been provided if the original form had been used, ensuring no loss of essential guidance. (b) If the Royal Arms appear on any listed form, they must appear on any modification of that form; however, the same format for the Royal Arms as used on the listed forms need not be used, provided there is a complete Royal Arms. (c) The Guide does not have the status of a Practice Direction nor the force of law; nevertheless, parties using the King's Bench Division are expected to act in accordance with it to assist in achieving the CPR overriding objective. The Guide should be read with the Civil Procedure Rules (CPR) and the supporting Practice Directions (PD), and it is not a substitute for the CPR; forms and related information are available on GOV.UK. It is assumed throughout the Guide that proceedings are intended to be in the Royal Courts of Justice, and the Guide is designed to facilitate proceedings started in the Central Office and to be updated regularly. [1. Introduction (p. 15)]
